**Five-Word Quatrains**

**Mountain Immortal**
A mountain immortal, unknown to all,
Girds his sword and enters the Great Tang.
Turning his head to gaze south and north,
He has no intent to return home.

**Yesterday at Nimo Temple**
Yesterday at Nimo Temple,
Early I sensed my robes turn yellow.
A black wind swept through in a gust—
A hundred ghosts all hid in silence.

**The Qin**
Seven strings unleash refined melodies,
Ten fingers pour forth the wind through pines.
Awakening from this floating-life dream,
The moon, serene, imprints the empty sky.

**Chess**
Black and white—my heart cannot decide,
When have I ever faced it at leisure?
Within the kalpa, myriad paths are perilous,
Life and death hang on a single move.

**Calligraphy**
Grieving the fall of Zhou’s latter days,
Scholars still search in vain.
Each bears benevolence and wisdom,
Yet who attains the heart of Confucius?

**Painting**
How lovely the hand of the artist,
Master of boundless samādhi’s power.
How many scenes of rivers and mountains—
All held within a single inch of heart.

---

**Four-Word Quatrains**

**Purity**
A single thought does not arise,
Whence could the myriad illusions spring?
Vast and empty, boundless—
Moon pale, wind clear.

**Stillness**
External realms do not intrude,
The inner spirit settles of itself.
A single point of numinous light—
Luminous, still, and bright.

**Dao/Way**
The principle of non-action runs deep,
Seeking it, one delves ever further.
Yet grasp it with an unforced hand—
This is called the Dao/Way.

**Virtue/Power**
Virtue, too, has no form,
Yet nothing it does not nurture.
When all things bear their bloom,
This is true virtue/power.

**Action**
Though the dharma-realm is vast,
It may be traversed and transcended.
Step with feet in the pure wind,
Grasp the bright moon in your hand.

**Abiding**
In motion, words fail,
In stillness, speech is void.
Forget both motion and stillness—
Rest here in the midst.

**Sitting**
The heart extinguished like cold ash,
The body forgotten like clod of earth.
Silent, dark, and profound—
Radiance illumines the three realms.

**Reclining**
The family tradition of purity,
The wondrous secret of the unseen and unheard.
Release the four great elements—
The myriad illusions all dissolve.

---

**Six-Word Poems**

Spring’s warmth, half-opened blossoms,
Wandering at ease upon the stone.
Alone I hold jade precepts and golden secrets,
Leisurely treading green moss and emerald moss.

Nineteen years I slept in an ancient cave,
Drank flowing radiance by the thousand cups.
When meeting others, speak not of worldly affairs—
Laughing, point to the white clouds’ comings and goings.

---

**Song of the Fallen**
Fallen, ah fallen—
At night, lodging in rustic villages,
By day, roaming the city walls.
When idle, I wander the verdant mountains,
When bored, peddle elixirs in the marketplace.

The coins I earn, not counted,
Spent on fine wine, poured for myself.
Drunk, my chants shake ghosts and gods,
Carefree as the sun sinks in the west.

---

**Seven-Word Regulated Verses**

**The Perfected One’s Departure**
When merits are complete, salvation’s meeting is hard to come by,
Again I hear you must depart from Apricot Immortal’s Altar.
At your staff’s tip, spring’s hues—a gourd of wine,
Atop your head, clouds pierce the Five Peaks’ crown.

The sea-turtle child, none recognize,
The mountain-burning talisman, ghosts dare not behold.
After the master’s gone, this body must age—
I beg you, give this poor scholar a bone-transforming elixir.

**The Golden Elixir**
A single grain of golden elixir ensures long life,
But true lead must refine the cyclical stems.
Fire draws the red phoenix’s marrow from the south,
Water seeks the black turtle’s essence from the northern sea.

The crucible follows the four seasons, uniting at the center,
The medicine moves with the three primals and eight trigrams.
After fasting and purifying, refine it nine times—
Know then that upon entering the mouth, gods and ghosts will tremble.

**The Perfected One by the Emerald Pool**
By the emerald pool, a true person appears,
His face like peach blossoms, his body like silver.
His temples show no gray—he has the art,
His complexion stays young—he has attained the divine.

Now is the time to ascend Penglai,
The yellow robes on the rack turn to clouds.
Though mulberry fields may turn to seas,
A single pill of elixir secures a thousand springs.

**Refining Cinnabar**
The furnace nurtures cinnabar—no gray at the temples,
Why trouble with fame and profit, dwelling among men?
I have met the perfected and received the divine medicine,
And rejoice with fellow seekers, smiling as we move.

Laozi’s Dao has been entrusted to me,
The Lesser Star permits me to ascend with it.
Fortunate to be gathered by the lofty ones,
In this world, I yield to you a life of leisure.

**Who Waits for Immortality?**
Who waits for immortality to be bestowed upon me?
I refine true qi within the immortal embryo.
I know well that I shall ascend to heaven in broad daylight,
Yet I have just descended into the red dust of the world.

When the White Tiger moves, rain and dew pour,
Where the Red Dragon plows, jasper and jade appear.
Swallow but a single grain of cinnabar medicine—
I shall soar into the azure clouds and never return.

**The Hidden Sage**
Amid the tumbled clouds, the starry capital appears,
Discerning the deeply concealed true man.
Drunk on green wine, he sleeps through sun and moon,
When the white duckweed’s wind stills, he fishes by rivers and lakes.

Ever aligning his bearing with heaven’s Dao,
He does not waste words on the world’s paths.
The mountain and water roads are distant, none reach them—
Do the reeds and thatch hold any news?

**The Crane as Chariot**
The crane serves as chariot, wine as provisions,
Transforming this into the land of long life, undying.
Even earth’s veins can be shortened,
How can human life not be made to lengthen?

In his hairpin, stars and constellations often appear,
Beneath his robe, sun and moon are often concealed.
If the common folk wish to meet him in person,
Day after day, they must not leave the path of mercury.

**The Magic Mushroom**
The magic mushroom has no seed, no root,
Yet it can be drunk, consumed, and revive the soul.
As long as mist and rosy clouds sustain the years,
Let the crow and hare race through the cosmos.

The infant only clings to the mother in the yang,
The crone must face the honored one atop her head.
Once attained, it does not return for a thousand ages—
No tombs or graves will be left for descendants.

**Who Understands These Words?**
Who in this world understands these words?
Do not hang fame and profit upon your heart’s field.
Casually pour out wine to the full,
When inspired, chant a hundred verses.

Beyond the world, mist and rosy clouds are my companions,
Within the gourd, sun and moon follow the fair one.
When the time comes and merits are complete, where shall I return?
I shall ride the cloud chariot straight into the grotto-heaven.

**The Emperor’s Son of the Mysterious Gate**
The Emperor’s Son of the Mysterious Gate sits at the center,
His life long and luminous, moved by the Jade Sovereign.
The world’s mountains and rivers harmonize with rain and dew,
Within his sleeve, sun and moon merge with Xiao and Xiang.

The Kan male is betrothed to the Jin family’s daughter,
The Li female, wedded in triumph, marries the Wooden Lad.
Truly, if husband and wife can hold fast to their resolve,
They shall establish teachings to entangle yin and yang.

**Retreat from the Mortal Frame**
How many years have passed since I shed my mortal frame?
Beyond the high green peaks, I feed on the mysterious frost.
Ancient snow on the blue mountains encircles my pine couch,
Cold clouds from the immortal’s palm refine the stone chamber.

I often climb the shell-paved towers to pluck tender jade herbs,
At times I break fragrant osmanthus in the Moon Palace.
Brilliant as brocade, it once opened for me—
Permitting me to wander the Five Emperors’ realm.

**A Whistle Toward the Distant Peak**
Pointing afar to the high peak, I let out a whistle—
Red radiance and purple mist arise before my face.
Often in the dusty market, none recognize me,
Yet when I reach the mountains, cranes come to greet me.

chunks.original_text: 杖弄玉蟾驱鬼魅，夜煎金鼎煮星辰。 他时若赴蓬莱洞，知我仙家有姓名。 堪笑时人问我家，杖檐云袖惹烟霞。 眉藏火电非他说，手种金莲不自夸。 三尺焦桐为活业，一壶春酒是生涯。 骑龙远出游三岛，夜后无人骯月华。 九曲江边坐外看，一条长路入天端。 庆云捧拥朝赤子，瑞气徘徊处白烟。 铅汞此时为至药，坎离今日结成丹。 功能济命无衰老，只在人心不是难。 修修修得到乾乾，方号人问一醉仙。 世上光阴催短景，洞中花木任长年。 形飞峭壁知龙骨，神在玄宫别有天。 唯愿先生频一顾，更休玄外问玄玄。 玄门玄理又玄玄，不死根元在汞铅。 知是一般真个卫，调和六一也同天。 玉京山下羊儿闹，金水河中石虎眠。 要妙能生真本体，精勤到处自如然。 公卿虽贵不曾酬，说着仙家便去游。 为抱石肝逢蜃海，因寻甜雪到瀛洲。 山川醉后壶中放，神鬼闲来匣裹收。 据见目前无个识，不如杯酒混凡流。 曾朝元始访仙家，恣上昆仑咽月华。 玉女搏拢苍懈秀，山童提楔白虾蛛。 时斟海内千年酒，惯摘壶中四序花。 今在人寰人不识，看看挥袖入烟霞。 火种丹田金自生，重重楼阁甚分明。 三千功行百旬日，万里蓬莱一日程。 形化阴司无鬼簿，玉都长是有仙名。 今晨得赴瑶池会，九节幢婶洞裹迎。 因看崔公入药镜，令人心地转分明。 阳龙言向离宫出，阴虎还於坎上生。 二物会时为道本，五方行尽得丹名。 修真上士如知此，定跨赤龙归玉京。 浮生不实为轻忽，纳服身藏奇异骨。 是非了达世问人，焉能物外通无物。 共语凡兮情兀兀，独自行兮轻拂拂。 一点刀圭五彩分，飞丹走入神仙窟。 莫怪爱吟天上诗，盖绿昤得世问稀。 惯餐王母洞中饭，曾着蓬莱洞裹衣。 马踏日轮红雾卷，凤衔月角碧云飞。 何时再控青丝辔，又掉金鞭入紫微。 黄芽白雪两飞金，行即高歌醉即吟。 日月暗扶君甲子，乾坤自与我知音。 精灵灭迹三清剑，风雨腾空一弄琴。 的当南游归甚处，莫教鹤去上天寻。 春来游荡到仙家，户列殊常二月花。 甲子尽推君行业，庚申得遂不须夸。 各有清灵天外性，肯忘浑浊弃骄奢。 千日功夫如会得，万年归去入烟霞。 云鬓双明骨更轻，自言寻鹤到蓬瀛。 日论草乐皆知味，问着神仙尽得名。 玲夜青龙穿碧洞，枕寒高卧白银城。 来春又拟携节去，为忆轩辕海上行。 龙精龟眼两相和，丈六童男不奈何。 九盏水中煎赤子，一轮火内养黄芽。 月圆自解离天网，功满方知出地罗。 半醉好吞鸾凤髓，劝君休更认弥随。 强居此景绝知音，野景虽多不合吟。 诗句若喧卿相耳，姓名还动帝王心。 道无腰带独佣卧，花竹皮冠尚懒簪。 除此更无余个事，一壶村酒一张琴。 华阳山裹多芝田，华阳山叟复延年。 青松垒畔高柯下，白云堆裹饮飞泉。 不寒不热神荡荡，束来西去气绵绵。 三千功满好归去，休与时人说洞天。 天生不散自然心，成败从来古与今。 得路应知皆出世，迷徒终是枉埋沈。 身边至乐须攻炼，物外丹砂且细寻。 咫尺洞房仙景在，莫随波浪没光阴。 自隐玄都不记春，几因沧海变成尘。 玉京殿裹朝元始，金阙宫中拜老君。 闷即驾乘千岁鹤，闲来高外九天云。 我今学得长生法，未肯传留与世人。 北帝南辰掌内看，潜通造化暗相传。
chunks.translated_text:
With staff I play the jade toad to drive away ghosts and specters,
By night I boil the golden tripod to cook the stars.
When one day I journey to Penglai Grotto,
Know that my immortal household bears a name.

How laughable are the worldly who ask of my home—
My cloud-sleeved staff brushes against mist and rosy clouds.
My brows conceal lightning, no idle boast,
My hands plant golden lotuses, yet I do not boast.

A three-foot scorched paulownia is my living craft,
A pot of spring wine is my livelihood.
Riding a dragon, I roam far to the Three Isles,
Beneath the night moon, none remain to sully its radiance.

By the winding river’s edge, I sit and gaze outward,
A single long path ascends to heaven’s end.
Auspicious clouds bear the Red Child in their embrace,
Auspicious vapors linger where white mists arise.

Lead and mercury now become the supreme medicine,
Kan and Li today fuse to form the elixir.
Its power can save lives, banishing age and decay—
It lies in the human heart, not in difficulty.

Cultivate, cultivate, cultivate until you reach Qian’s perfection,
Then you may be called the world’s drunken immortal.
In the world, time hurries short-lived scenes,
Within the grotto, flowers and trees enjoy eternal years.

My form soars the sheer cliffs, knowing dragon bones,
My spirit dwells in the Mysterious Palace, another heaven apart.
I only wish the master would glance my way often,
No need to seek mysteries beyond the mystery.

The mystery of the Mystic Gate, the principle of the mystery—again mysterious,
The root of deathlessness lies in mercury and lead.
Know this as the true and sole defense,
Harmonizing the Six-and-One, it too aligns with heaven.

Beneath Jade Capital Mountain, lambs frolic,
By Golden Water River, stone tigers slumber.
The subtlest art can generate the true original body,
Diligence in every place brings effortless mastery.

Though nobles and ministers are honored, I do not respond,
Mentioning the immortal’s life, I depart to wander.
For holding a liver of stone, I met the mirage sea,
In seeking sweet snow, I reached Yingzhou.

After mountains and rivers grow drunk, they are stored within the gourd,
When gods and ghosts grow idle, they are gathered into the casket.
Seeing none here recognize me,
I would rather blend with the mortal stream over cups of wine.

Once I paid homage to the Primordial One to visit the immortals,
Freely ascending Kunlun to sip the moon’s essence.
Jade maidens gathered the verdant beauty of pines,
Mountain lads carried white jade tablets.

From time to time, I poured the thousand-year wine of the sea,
Accustomed to plucking the four-season flowers within the gourd.
Now in the mortal realm, none recognize me,
Soon I shall wave my sleeves and enter mist and rosy clouds.

Fire sown in the cinnabar field, gold naturally grows,
Layer upon layer of pavilions, so distinct.
Three thousand merits in a hundred days,
A journey of ten thousand miles to Penglai in a single day.

My form transforms in the netherworld, no ghostly register holds me,
In the Jade Capital, my immortal name endures.
This morning I attend the Jasper Pool assembly,
Nine-tiered banners and streamers welcome me within the grotto.

Gazing upon Master Cui’s *Mirror of Ingested Medicine*,
My heart’s ground grows ever clearer.
The yang dragon speaks, emerging from the Li Palace,
The yin tiger returns, born upon the Kan trigram.

When these two meet, they form the root of the Dao,
Traversing the five directions, they attain the elixir’s name.
If cultivators of truth know this,
They shall surely ride the red dragon back to Jade Capital.

Floating life is insubstantial, treated with neglect,
Ingesting and concealing, the body holds wondrous bones.
Having understood right and wrong, I question worldly folk—
How can they transcend things to commune with nothingness?

Speaking with mortals, my feelings grow dull,
Walking alone, I lightly brush past.
A single speck of powder divides into five hues,
Flying elixir enters the grotto of immortals.

Do not wonder that I love to chant celestial poems,
For I have rarely heard such in the mortal world.
Accustomed to dining on the Queen Mother’s grotto rice,
I once wore the Penglai grotto’s robes.

My steed treads the sun’s wheel, red mist unfurls,
The phoenix bears the moon’s horn, azure clouds take flight.
When shall I again rein the green-silk bridle,
And brandish my golden whip to enter the Purple Tenuity?

Yellow sprout and white snow, both transmute into gold,
Walking, I sing loudly; drunk, I chant.
Sun and moon secretly support your chronicles,
Heaven and earth naturally befriend me.

Spirits vanish at the trace of the Three Clarities’ sword,
Wind and rain soar as I play my zither.
Where shall I return after my southern journey?
Do not let the crane depart to seek me in heaven.

Spring arrives, I wander to the immortal’s home,
Where doors display extraordinary February blossoms.
The cyclical stems reveal your life’s work,
The cyclical branches fulfill your destiny—no need for boasting.

Each possesses a pure, numinous nature beyond heaven,
How could one forget the turbid and cast aside arrogance?
If you grasp the thousand-day effort,
You shall return after ten thousand years into mist and rosy clouds.

Cloud-like tresses gleam, my bones grow lighter,
I say I seek the crane to reach Penglai and Yingzhou.
Discussing herbs and music all day, I know their savor,
Asking of immortals, I learn all their names.

On clear nights, the azure dragon pierces the emerald grotto,
In cold repose, I lie high in the White Silver City.
Come spring, I shall again take up my staff to depart,
Recalling Xuanyuan’s journey upon the sea.

Dragon essence and tortoise eyes harmonize,
The sixteen-foot lad cannot endure.
Nine cups of water simmer the Red Child,
A single wheel of fire nurtures the yellow sprout.

The moon, full, naturally dissolves the heavenly net,
Only when merits are complete does one know how to escape the earthly snare.
Half-drunk, I happily swallow phoenix marrow,
I urge you, no longer mistake the fleeting for the eternal.

Forcing myself to dwell in this scene, bereft of kindred spirits,
Though wild scenes abound, they do not suit my chant.
If my verses clamor in the ears of ministers,
My name shall stir the hearts of emperors.

The Dao has no sash, I sleep alone,
Flowered bamboo hat and bark crown, I am too lazy to don.
Beyond this, I have no other affairs—
A pot of rustic wine, a zither.

Within Huayang Mountain lie many fields of mushrooms,
The old man of Huayang Mountain further extends his years.
Beneath the towering boughs by the verdant pine mounds,
I drink the flying spring amid white clouds.

Neither cold nor hot, my spirit sways,
Coming from the west, departing to the east, my qi flows gently.
When three thousand merits are complete, it is time to return,
Do not speak of the grotto-heaven to worldly folk.

Heaven-born, the natural heart does not scatter,
Success and failure have ever been thus, from ancient times to now.
Those who find the path know all shall transcend the world,
The deluded forever sink in vain.

The supreme joy at one’s side demands refinement,
Beyond things, the cinnabar sand must be carefully sought.
The immortal’s realm lies within the grotto chamber, a hand’s span away,
Do not follow the waves and squander your radiance.

I have hidden in the Mysterious Capital, forgetting spring,
How many times has the azure sea turned to dust?
Within the Jade Capital’s hall, I paid homage to the Primordial One,
In the Golden Gate Palace, I bowed to the Old Lord.

When bored, I ride the thousand-year crane,
When at leisure, I soar beyond the nine heavens’ clouds.
Now I have learned the art of longevity,
Yet I am not willing to pass it on to the world.

Gazing within the palms of the Northern Emperor and Southern Star,
I secretly penetrate creation’s mysteries.

---

**Note:** *Kan* (坎) and *Li* (离) refer to the trigrams representing Water and Fire in the *Yijing*, often symbolizing yin and yang forces in Daoist internal alchemy. *Six-and-One* (六一) may refer to the Six-and-One Mudrā or a specific alchemical formula. *Red Child* (赤子) and *Yellow Sprout* (黄芽) are technical terms in Daoist internal alchemy, symbolizing purified essence and generative energy. *Jade Capital* (玉京) and *Purple Tenuity* (紫微) are celestial realms in Daoist cosmology. *Three Clarities* (三清) refers to the highest Daoist heavens. *Xuanyuan* (轩辕) is the Yellow Emperor, a legendary Daoist immortal. *Cyclical stems* (甲子) and *branches* (庚申) refer to the traditional Chinese sexagenary cycle used in divination and timekeeping. *Huayang* (华阳) is a sacred mountain in Daoist tradition. *Primordial One* (元始) and *Old Lord* (老君) are epithets for Laozi and other Daoist deities.

chunks.original_text: 金锤袖裹居元宅，玉户星宫降上玄。 举世尽皆寻此道，谁人空裹得玄关。 明明道在堪消息，日月滩头去又还。 日影光中合自然，奔雷走电入中原。 长骑赤马居束殿，大启朱门浮碧泉。 怒拔昆吾歌圣化，喜陪孤月贺新年。 方知却是神仙物，得在仁人始授传。 六龙齐贺得升乾，头角潜通造化权。 真道每昤秋月淡，至言长运碧波寒。 昼乘白鹿游蓬岛，夜顶金冠立古坛。 一载已成千岁药，谁人将袖染尘寰。 五岳滩头景象新，仁人方达杳冥身。 天歌运道三元静，地脉通来万物生。 且晓谷神修此道，罢论理性欲寻真。 明明说向中黄路，霹雳声中自得神。 欲陪仙倡得身轻，飞过蓬莱彻上清。 朱顶鹤来云外接，紫鳞鱼向海中迎。 姐娥嫩桂花先吐，王母仙桃子渐成。 下瞰日输天欲晓，定知人世久长生。 四海皆忙一个闲，人人口内说尘绿。 知君有道来山上，何似无名住世问。 十二楼台藏秘诀，五千言内隐玄关。 方知鼎贮星辰药，乞取刀圭一粒看。 割断繁华掉却荣，便从初得是长生。 曾於锦水留蝉蜕，又到蓬莱别姓名。 三往往来无否泰，一尘尘在世人情。 不知功满归何处，直跨苍龙上玉京。 当年诗价满皇都，掉臂西归是丈夫。 万顷白云独自有，一枝仙桂阿谁无。 等闲渭曲渔翁引，醉上莲峰道士扶。 他日与君重际会，竹溪茅舍夜相呼。 金锤灼灼舞天阶，独自骑龙去又来。 高卧白云观日窟，闲眠秋月擘天开。 离花片片乾坤产，坎药翩翩造化裁。 晚醉九岩回首望，北郁山下骨皑皑。 结交常与道情深，日月随他出又沈。 苦要目通云外鹤，直须志炼水中金。 丹成只恐乾坤窄，饵了宁忧疾患侵。 未去瑶台犹混世、不妨杯酒喜闲吟。 偶拥琴剑下烟萝，何幸今朝喜暂过。 比相本来皆似可，针医偏更效无多。 仙经尝读三千卷，古法曾持十二科。 些小仙方如不信，金阶撒手试看么。 倾倒华阳醉再三，骑龙遇晚下南垒。 眉因拍剑流星电，衣为眠云惹碧岚。 金液变来成雨露，玉都归去老松杉。 曾将铁镜照神鬼，霹雳搜寻水满潭。 铁镜烹金火满空，碧潭龙外夕阳中。 麒麟意合乾坤地，懈露机关日月东。 三尺剑横双水岸，五丁冠顶百神宫，闲铺羽翠拘神窟，自着金莲造化功。 随绿信业任浮沈，似水如云一片心。 两卷道经三尺剑，一条华杖七弦琴。 壶中有药逢人施，腹内新诗遇客吟，一嚼汞添千载寿，一丸丹点一斤金。 半醉岔前度几秋，骑龙驾凤永无忧。 王侯宰相全不爱，坎离两件是奇筹。 独坐蓬莱观宇宙，抽剑眉问海上游。 为见不平心裹事，解冤雪耻取人头。 琴剑酒棋龙鹤虎，逍遥落魄永无忧。 闲骑白鹿游三岛，时驾青牛过十洲。 碧洞远观明月掌，青山高隐伴云头。 时人若要还如此，名利浮华即便休。 紫极宫中我自知，精磨神剑剑还飞。 先差玉子开南殿，后遣青龙入北微。 九鼎黄芽栖睡凤，一躯仙骨养灵芝。 蓬莱不是人安处，只怕愚人泄世机。 回身方始出埃尘，造化功夫只在人。 早使亢龙抛地网，岂知白虎出天真。 绵绵有路谁留我，默默忘言自合神。 击剑夜探归甚处，披星带月斩麒麟。 看尽闲闲过落花，一回舞剑一吁嗟。 常忧白日光阴促，每恨青天道路赊。 本志不求名与利，元心只慕水兼霞。 世问万种浮沈事，谁人达理似余家。

Within golden sleeves resides the Primordial Abode,
Jade gates and starry palaces descend from the Supreme Mystery.
The world entire seeks this Dao—
Yet who, in vain, grasps the Mysterious Pass?

Brightly the Dao abides, awaiting its reckoning;
By the shoals of sun and moon, it departs and returns.
Within the radiance of daylight, it merges with nature,
As thunder races and lightning strikes the Central Plain.

Ever riding the crimson steed, dwelling in the Eastern Hall,
Grandly unsealed the vermilion gates, floating upon azure springs.
Fiercely drawing the Kunwu blade to sing of sagely transformation,
Joyfully accompanying the solitary moon to celebrate the new year.

Only then is it known as the immortals’ treasure,
Bestowed solely upon the virtuous for transmission.
Six dragons in unison hail ascension to Qian,
Their horns subtly wielding the power of creation.

The true Dao often hums beneath the pale autumn moon,
The profound word ever flows through the chill jade waves.
By day, riding the white stag through Peng Isle,
By night, crowned in gold, standing atop the ancient altar.

A single year yields the elixir of a thousand ages—
Who would sully their sleeves with the dust of the mortal realm?
Upon the shoals of the Five Peaks, the scene renews,
The virtuous one alone attains the formless body.

Heavenly songs convey the Dao as the Three Origins settle,
Earth’s veins pulse, bringing forth the myriad beings.
Awaken to the Valley Spirit and cultivate this Way,
Cease discourse on principle and seek the real.

Brightly expounded along the path of the Central Yellow,
Amidst the thunder’s roar, one attains the divine.
Longing to join the immortal maidens, the body grows light,
Soaring past Penglai to reach the Highest Clarity.

Crimson-crested cranes arrive from beyond the clouds,
Purple-scaled fish welcome from the sea’s depths.
Chang’e’s tender osmanthus blooms first,
The Queen Mother’s immortal peaches gradually ripen.

Gazing down, the sun’s chariot hastens toward dawn—
Surely the mortal world has long attained longevity.
The four seas bustle, yet one remains at leisure,
Each mouth speaks of worldly dust.

Knowing you possess the Dao, I come to this mountain—
How could nameless obscurity compare to dwelling in the world?
Twelve towers and terraces conceal secret formulas,
Within five thousand words lies hidden the Mysterious Pass.

Only then is it known that the crucible stores the elixir of stars,
Begging but a single *daogui* grain to behold.
Severing the bonds of splendor, casting aside glory,
From the first attainment, one is everlasting.

Once by the brocade waters, a cicada’s molt was left behind,
Again at Penglai, a name was shed.
Thrice journeying, untouched by fortune or misfortune,
A speck of dust lingers in the world’s affections.

Unknowing where the fulfilled merit leads,
One rides the azure dragon straight to Jade Capital.
In those years, poetry’s worth filled the imperial capital,
Yet with a careless wave of the arm, the true man departed west.

Alone, he possessed ten thousand acres of white clouds,
Who else might claim a branch of the immortal osmanthus?
Casually, the fisherman of Wei’s bend beckoned,
Drunk, he ascended Lotus Peak, supported by a Daoist.

One day, we shall meet again,
By the bamboo stream and thatched hut, calling through the night.

The golden hammer gleams, dancing upon the celestial steps,
Alone, he rides the dragon, departing and returning.
High he reclines in the white clouds, observing the sun’s cavern,
Leisurely he slumbers beneath the autumn moon, cleaving the heavens.

The *li* flower, petal by petal, is born of heaven and earth,
The *kan* medicine, fluttering, is shaped by creation.
Evening drunk among the nine peaks, turning to gaze—
Beneath the northern dark mountain, bones lie pale.

Friendship is ever deep with those of the Dao,
As sun and moon follow them, rising and setting.
To suffer longing for the crane beyond the clouds,
One must forge the gold within the water with resolve.

When the elixir is complete, the cosmos may seem too narrow,
Yet once ingested, what fear of illness or harm?
Not yet departed to the Jasper Terrace, still mingling in the world,
No harm in a cup of wine, delighting in idle verse.

By chance, embracing lute and sword, descending through misty vines—
What fortune to pass through this day!
Comparisons are all alike, yet seem fitting,
But acupuncture and medicine yield little effect.

The immortal classics have been read—three thousand scrolls,
Ancient methods once held—twelve disciplines.
If these minor immortal recipes are doubted,
Step forth on the golden steps and see for yourself.

Overturning Huayang in drunken revelry again and again,
Riding the dragon at dusk, descending to the southern ramparts.
Brows furrowed, striking the sword like streaking meteors,
Robes, from sleeping amid clouds, cling to emerald mist.

The golden liquid transforms into rain and dew,
Returning to the Jade Capital, the aged pines and cedars.
Once, an iron mirror was used to illuminate spirits and ghosts,
Thunder rumbled, searching as water filled the pool.

The iron mirror smelted gold as fire filled the sky,
Beyond the azure pool, dragons danced in the evening sun.
The qilin’s intent harmonized with heaven and earth,
The mechanism of dew and mist lay in the sun and moon’s east.

A three-foot sword lay across the twin rivers’ banks,
A five-spiked crown atop the hundred spirits’ palace.
Leisurely spreading kingfisher plumes to bind the spirit’s cave,
Donning golden lotuses to enact creation’s work.

Following karmic deeds, drifting and sinking,
Like water or cloud, a single heart.
Two scrolls of Daoist scriptures, a three-foot sword,
A flowering staff, a seven-stringed zither.

Within the gourd, medicine awaits to be given to others,
In the belly, new poems meet travelers to be recited.
A single bite of mercury adds a thousand years of life,
A single pill of elixir transmutes a catty of gold.

Half-drunk before the forked path, how many autumns have passed?
Riding dragons and phoenixes, forever without care.
Kings, ministers, and chancellors are not loved—
Only the *kan* and *li* are the wondrous tally.

Alone seated on Penglai, observing the cosmos,
Drawing the sword from the brow, roaming the seas.
Witnessing injustice stirring within the heart,
Resolving grievances, avenging shame, taking heads.

Lute, sword, wine, and chess—dragon, crane, and tiger,
Carefree and untroubled, forever without worry.
Leisurely riding the white stag through the three isles,
At times driving the green ox across the ten continents.

From afar in the azure grotto, the bright moon rests in the palm,
High in the green mountains, concealed beside the clouds.
If mortals wish to be thus,
Let fame and profit’s floating splendor be cast aside at once.

Within the Purple Tenuity Palace, I know myself,
Sharpening the spirit-sword until it flies of its own accord.
First dispatching jade lads to open the southern hall,
Then sending the green dragon into the northern darkness.

Nine crucibles harbor the Yellow Sprout, where the sleeping phoenix roosts,
A single immortal’s frame nurtures the numinous fungus.
Peng Isle is no place for mortals to dwell—
Only fear the foolish may leak the world’s secrets.

Turning the body, one at last emerges from the dust,
The work of creation lies solely in man.
Early, the exalted dragon casts off the earth’s net,
How could the White Tiger emerge from the celestial truth?

Endless the path—who would detain me?
Silent, wordless, naturally merging with the divine.
Striking the sword by night, where does one return?
Clad in stars and moonlight, slaying the qilin.

Watching idly as blossoms fall,
Each sword dance met with a sigh.
Ever anxious that the white sun’s light hastens time,
Ever resentful that the azure heavens’ road is distant.

The original intent sought neither fame nor profit,
The primordial heart only admired water and mist.
The world’s myriad affairs drift and sink—
Who understands principle as does my family?

Ten thousand matters in the world drift and settle,
Who attains reason like my household?
chunks.overlap_context: energy. *Jade Capital* (玉京) and *Purple Tenuity* (紫微) are celestial realms in Daoist cosmology. *Three Clarities* (三清) refers to the highest Daoist heavens. *Xuanyuan* (轩辕) is the Yellow Emperor, a legendary Daoist immortal. *Cyclical stems* (甲子) and *branches* (庚申) refer to the traditional Chinese sexagenary cycle used in divination and timekeeping. *Huayang* (华阳) is a sacred mountain in Daoist tradition. *Primordial One* (元始) and *Old Lord* (老君) are epithets for Laozi and other Daoist deities.

chunks.original_text: 日为陈解月吁丹，华夏诸侯肉眼看。 仁义异如胡越异，世情难似泰衡难。 八仙炼就终成创，四海磨来照瞻寒。 平却不平千万万，拍剑骑龙上九天。 别来涨水浸束风，醉眼昤情慵不慵。 轰振乾坤金剑吼，烹煎日月玉炉封。 杖遥楚甸三千里，鹤翕秦川一万重。 为报晋城仙子道，再期春色会莲峰。 髡头血滴眼如锻，吐气云生怒世问。 叵耐不平千种事，须期一诀荡凶顽。 蛟龙斩处翻沧海，暴虎除时拔远山。 为灭无情兼负义，剑光星染点痕斑。 雨雪霏霏天已暮，金锺满劝抚焦桐。 诗吟席上未移刻，剑舞筵前疾似风。 何事行括常午夜，忽然怒目便腾空。 不知谁是亏忠孝，拥个人头入坐中。 风霜三尺鬼神愁，大袖高冠得自由。 喜极夸前歌越曲，怒来眉际拔昊钩。 自从碧海离三岛，不上朱门谒五侯。 半醉夸然攘臂立，问谁怀抱有冤俨。 未炼还丹且炼心，丹成方觉道源探。 每留客有钱沽酒，谁信君无药点金。 洞裹风雷归掌握，壶中日月在胸襟。 神仙事业人难会，养性长生自意吟。 铁牛耕地种金钱，刻石童儿把贯穿。 一粒粟中藏世界，半升铛内煮山川。 白须老子眉垂地，碧眼胡儿手指天。 若向此中玄会得，此玄玄后更无玄。 箕星勖宿下长天，凡景宁教不夸然。 龙出水来鳞甲就，鹤冲天去羽毛全。 尘中教化千人眼，世上难知尔雅篇。 自是凡流福命薄，忍将微妙略轻传。 闲来摆臂入天门，拂袂徐徐撮彩云。 无语下窥黄谷子，破颜平揖紫霞君。 拟登瑶殿偎金久，回访瀛洲看日输。 恰值姐娥才宴会，琼浆新熟味氤氲。 曾随刘阮醉桃源，未醒人间欠酒钱。 一领布裘权且当，九天回日却归还。 凤毛袄子非为贵，狐白裘裳欲比难。 只此世间无价宝，不然火裹试烧看。 因思往事却成敢，曾读千文第十三。 武氏死时应室女，陈王殁后是童男。 两输日月从他载，九个江猜一檐担。 尽日无人话消息，一壶春酒且醺酣。 垂袖腾腾彻世尘，胡芦携却数游巡。 利名身外终非道，龙虎门前辨取真。 不觉梦魂朝紫府，数年踪迹隐埃尘。 华阴市内如相见，不是寻常卖药人。 万卷仙经三尺琴，刘安闻说是知音。 杖头春色一壶酒，炉内丹砂不点金。 几度醉眠山路口，闲来游钓洞庭心。 相逢相遇知多少，只恐冲天没处寻。 曾战蚩尤玉府前，六龙高驾振呜銮。 指南车后随金鼓，皂蠢旗傍带铁冠。 醉持黑髭三岛黯，怒抽霜剑十洲寒。 轩辕世代横行后，直隐探严久觅难。 头发苍浪声似锺，貌如冰雪骨如松。 匣中宝剑时时吼，袖裹金锤逞武风。 会饮酒时为伴倡，能昤诗句便参同。 年来定赴昆仑宴，骑个生狞九色龙。 神仙户入黄宫阙，将相门开白玉京。 可使洞中无好景，其余天下有众生。 携琴独步闲随鹤，匣剑辉霞待斩鲸。 进退两楹俱未失，凭君与我指前程。 世情阴雨疑相孤，电闪雷声振八都。 长去乱山添雾露，不来平地救憔枯。 原融春色留声振，结构秋风害旅途。 弄却三问破草舍，临时看得几年无。 七言绝句 秋景萧条叶乱飞，庭松影裹坐移时。 云迷鹤驾何方去，仙洞朝元失我期。 捉得金精作命基，日魂束畔月华西。 於中炼取长生药，服了还同天地齐。 朝泛浮名暮却还，洞中日月我为天。 匣中宝剑时时吼，不遇志人誓不传。 剑起星奔万里诛，风雷随处雨声赢。

The sun unfolds its explanations, the moon sighs its cinnabar,
The lords of Hua-Xia behold with mortal eyes.
Benevolence and righteousness differ as Hu and Yue differ,
Worldly sentiments are as hard to fathom as Mount Tai and Mount Heng.

The Eight Immortals refine and forge to final creation,
The Four Seas grind and polish, their gaze cold and piercing.
What is level yet not level—ten thousand times ten thousand,
Striking the sword, riding the dragon to the Ninth Heaven.

Since parting, the rising waters drown the east wind,
Drunken eyes, lingering emotions—weary or not?
The golden sword roars, shaking heaven and earth,
The jade crucible seals the boiling of sun and moon.

Staff in hand, three thousand *li* to the lands of Chu,
Crane’s wings span ten thousand layers over Qin’s rivers.
To report to the immortal of Jin City:
We shall meet again in spring’s hues at Lotus Peak.

Shaven head, blood dripping, eyes like forge-fire,
Breath exhaled, clouds rise—rage at the world’s questions.
Intolerable, the thousand injustices of this age,
Must seek a single decisive strike to sweep away the fierce and stubborn.

Where the flood-dragon is slain, the seas churn,
When the raging tiger is felled, distant mountains are uprooted.
To extinguish the heartless and betrayers of virtue,
The sword’s light, star-stained, leaves its marks.

Rain and snow fall thickly, the sky already dusk,
Golden goblets filled, soothing the scorched paulownia.
Poems chanted at the feast, not a moment passed,
The sword dances before the banquet, swift as the wind.

Why does one’s conduct ever linger past midnight?
Suddenly, eyes blazing, one leaps into the void.
Who knows who lacks loyalty and filial piety?
A head is seized and brought to the seat.

Three feet of frost and wind—ghosts and spirits grieve,
With wide sleeves and tall cap, one attains freedom.
Overjoyed, one boasts and sings the songs of Yue,
Enraged, the brows arch, drawing the sword of the heavens.

Since leaving the three isles of the azure sea,
One no longer visits the vermilion gates of the five marquises.
Half-drunk, one rolls up sleeves and stands defiant,
Asking who harbors grievances so grave.

Before refining the elixir, refine the heart,
Only when the cinnabar is complete does one grasp the source of the Dao.
Often, guests are kept with money to buy wine,
Who believes one lacks the medicine to transmute gold?

Within the cave, wind and thunder are grasped in the palm,
In the gourd, sun and moon rest in the breast.
The work of immortals is hard for men to comprehend,
Cultivating nature, attaining long life—one hums to oneself.

The iron ox plows the earth, sowing golden coins,
The stone boy strings them through.
A single grain of millet holds a world,
Half a *sheng* of the cauldron boils mountains and rivers.

The white-bearded elder’s brows touch the ground,
The blue-eyed barbarian points to the sky.
If you can fathom this mystery,
Beyond this mystery, there is no further mystery.

The *Ji* star and *Xu* constellation descend from the long sky,
How can the common scene not be marveled at?
The dragon emerges from the water, its scales complete,
The crane soars to the heavens, its feathers whole.

Teaching transformation amidst the dust, a thousand eyes watch,
Yet in the world, few understand the *Erya*.
It is only that the common folk’s fortune and fate are meager,
They cannot bear to lightly transmit the subtle and wondrous.

At leisure, one swings an arm and enters the Gate of Heaven,
Sweeping the sleeves, slowly gathering the colored clouds.
Silent, one gazes down at the Yellow Valley’s child,
Smiling, one bows to the Purple Mist Lord.

Planning to linger by the Jade Palace, leaning on gold,
Returning to visit Yingzhou, watching the sun’s decline.
Just as the Moon Goddess holds her feast,
The nectar newly brewed, its fragrance wafting.

Once followed Liu and Ruan, drunk in Peach Blossom Spring,
Yet to wake in the mortal world, still owing wine money.
A hempen robe serves for now,
When the sun returns from the Ninth Heaven, it shall be repaid.

Phoenix-feathered robes are not prized,
Even the white fox’s fur cannot compare.
This alone is the world’s priceless treasure—
If not, try burning it in fire to see.

Reflecting on past events, one grows bold,
Having read the *Thousand Character Classic*, the thirteenth chapter.
When Empress Wu died, she was a maiden,
When King Chen perished, he was a boy.

Two chariots of sun and moon, let them bear the load,
Nine rivers’ guesses hang from a single eave’s pole.
All day, no one speaks of news,
A pot of spring wine, one drinks to intoxication.

Sleeves hanging, one soars beyond the world’s dust,
A gourd carried, one roams several times.
Fame and profit, outside the body, are not the Dao,
At the Dragon-Tiger Gate, discern the true.

Unwittingly, the dream-soul journeys to the Purple Palace,
For years, one’s traces have hidden in the dust of the world.
If we meet again in Huayin’s market,
It will not be as an ordinary medicine-seller.

Ten thousand scrolls of immortal scriptures, a three-foot zither,
Liu An, hearing of this, is a kindred spirit.
A staff’s tip holds spring’s hues, a pot of wine,
In the crucible, cinnabar—not transmuted gold.

Several times, drunk and sleeping at the mountain’s mouth,
At leisure, one fishes the heart of Dongting.
How many times have we met and encountered?
Only fear that, soaring to the heavens, there will be no place to seek.

Once battled Chi You before the Jade Palace,
Six dragons high, the jade chimes resounding.
Behind the south-pointing chariot, the golden drums followed,
Beside the black turtle banner, the iron-crowned marched.

Drunk, clutching the black beard, the three isles darkened,
Enraged, drawing the frost-edged sword, the ten continents chilled.
After the age of the Yellow Emperor’s reign,
One has long sought the deep and stern, yet found it hard.

Hair wild as waves, voice like a bell,
Face like ice and snow, bones like pine.
In the scabbard, the treasured sword roars ceaselessly,
In the sleeve, the golden hammer displays martial prowess.

When drinking, one is a companion and singer,
When chanting poems, one delves into the *Cantong Qi*.
In recent years, one is bound for the Kunlun feast,
Riding a fierce, nine-colored dragon.

The gates of immortals open to the Yellow Palace,
The gates of generals and ministers to the White Jade Capital.
If even the caves lack fine scenes,
What remains in the world but the multitudes?

Carrying the zither, one strolls idly, following the crane,
In the scabbard, the sword gleams with rosy clouds, awaiting the slaying of the whale.
Advancing or retreating, neither is lost,
I leave it to you to point the way forward.

Worldly sentiments, like yin rain, seem to isolate,
Lightning flashes, thunder shakes the eight directions.
Long gone, the chaotic mountains add mist and dew,
Not coming to the level earth to save the withered and emaciated.

The spring’s hues of Yuan and Rong linger in the echoes,
The autumn winds of construction harm the traveler’s path.
Playing with the three questions, the thatched hut is broken,
At the moment, how many years will one see?

**Seven-character quatrains**

Autumn’s scene desolate, leaves scatter in flight,
Beneath the courtyard pine’s shadow, time passes as one sits.
Clouds obscure the crane’s chariot—where has it gone?
The immortal’s cave at dawn misses my appointed time.

Seizing the golden essence to make the foundation of life,
At the sun’s eastern edge, the moon’s western glow.
Within it, refine the elixir of long life,
Consuming it, one becomes equal to heaven and earth.

Morning chases floating fame, evening discards it,
Within the cave, the sun and moon—I am the sky.
In the scabbard, the treasured sword roars ceaselessly,
Not meeting a man of resolve, it vows not to be transmitted.

The sword rises, stars flee, executing ten thousand *li*,
Wind and thunder follow, the sound of rain prevails.

**The man’s head rolls yet his words remain,**
Striding high, chanting past the Five Lakes.
"Master! Master!"—his visage fierce and grim,
He draws his sword to strike where clouds err.
Three sharp shouts ring out in rapid succession,
With a *clang*, the man falls empty into the void.

"Master! Master! Do not tarry,
The Dao must be passed, the sword held in reverence.
Today we meet by the sea’s edge,
Let us hasten to the village wine and roam as one."

His brows bristle, fierce spirit surging,
A single bound—ten thousand *li* through the sky.
The three-foot sword in the scabbard on his back,
Heaven’s blade to slay the unjust.
Sharpening the green-wind three-foot sword,
The golden hammer in his sleeve, never wielded in vain.
If one is a man of resolve, he must be repaid,
How could he let others say he is no true man?

With bushy brows and towering resolve, his voice like thunder,
Hearing of grievances, he sets down his cup.
Sword in hand, he soars a thousand *li* through the sky,
Parting at the first watch, returning by the second.
This morning, rising in the pitch-black dark,
A thousand *li* to avenge, all in an instant.
From his sleeve, he pours out a dead man’s head,
His mouth still muttering, *"De, de."*

By South Mountain’s edge, we meet again,
Grasping hands, earnest words ring like bells.
"Since you mastered the sword after we parted,
Where there are dragons, you slay dragons."
Half a day’s journey spans the world,
No need to ride phoenix or mount dragon.
By chance, in a game of skill, his divine sword flew,
Shattering the first peak of Zhongnan.
Morning roams Nanyue, evening Cangwu,
His sleeve holds a green serpent, his gall bold.
Thrice entering Yueyang, none recognize him,
Chanting aloud as he flies past Dongting Lake.

To study the Dao, one must be utterly poor,
A few coins only in his purse.
If one asks of my method of cultivation,
I point afar to the sun and moon on the horizon.
Unbetraying the Three Lights, unbetraying men,
Neither deceiving the divine nor the destitute.
If one asks of my method of cultivation,
Only tend the field of the heart to nurture this body.
Three *mu* of cinnabar field, no seeds to sow,
When planting, one must have the Red Dragon plow.
I once taught others to sow this child,
But without understanding cultivation, the Dao does not grow.

No need for matchmakers to seek without,
The Returned Elixir is gathered within the body.
Do not say the Great Dao is hard to attain,
It is only that one’s effort has not reached its peak.
Drink wine—let it be a hundred cups,
Eastward bound, floating like a matchmaker’s ladder.
If the essence of the sun unites with the moon’s glow,
A bright pearl will rise.
Flickering, tiger and dragon, divine beings take flight,
Rely on this body’s work—do not go astray.
When transmitting, it must be with the power of heaven and earth,
Then penetrate the Three Clarities, pass through the Purple Tenuity.

In the depths of the Primal Sea, life’s pivot lies hidden,
Within dwells the Yellow Lad, the Jade Emperor’s Lord.
The White Snow Divine Talisman conceals the Maiden of Nü,
The Spirit’s Origin is guarded by the Ten Lords of Yuan.
Do not wonder why news from Jasper Pool is rare,
Only because worldly affairs veil heaven’s mechanism.
If one finds fire within water,
A Jade Lad ascends to the Great Subtlety.

Clapping hands, dancing with gourd,
Crossing ridges, piercing clouds, his staff flies.
Coming and going eight thousand *li* in half a day,
By the southern bank of Jinzhou, a pine gate stands.
Tipping the gourd, casting aside the zither,
He strides straight up Ox-Crouching Peak.
Water flies on stone, bursting like snow,
Standing to gaze at heaven, sitting to chant.

The flask like gold, the jade child yellow,
Ascending and descending, replenishing divine sustenance.
The Three Origins unite in a year of stillness,
In this heaven, the sun and moon endure long.
The Elbow-Transmitted Cinnabar Script—a thousand-year art,
Reciting the *Yellow Court* in two scrolls.
In the crane’s abode, the ancient altar within the locust’s shade,
No human trace, the door ever ajar.

My home originally dwells in Heaven’s Pivot,
Scattered white clouds lock the stone steps.
Penglai’s eastern sea lies beyond ten thousand *li*,
Yet I return as before, the path unerring.
The Lotus Peak Daoist, lofty and pure,
Never descends from Lotus Peak through the years.
At night, he bows to the stars, his jade hairpin cold,
At dawn, dragon and tiger open the golden tripod, seething.

I myself forget the spirit, my heart delights,
Striding over water, piercing clouds to visit.
I do not ask of the Yellow Sprout or the Elbow’s Prescription,
How can the wondrous Dao’s subtlety be spoken?
If men of this age wish to go to Yingzhou,
First pass the towering Twelve Towers.
There, thunder and lightning roar,
A pool of golden water flows eastward.

Alone on the high mountain, gazing at the Eight Capitals,
After the black clouds scatter, the moon remains solitary.
In the boundless cosmos, men numberless,
How few true men are men of resolve?

The fire-wheel, small, emerges from the divine continent,
Straining to bear it with an iron ox.
With a red heart, bearing it to Kunlun’s summit,
Who knows the Returned Elixir is called the Purple Journey?

Nurture the spirit-root with essence, the spirit with *qi*,
Beyond this truth, there is no other truth.
The immortals are unwilling to speak plainly,
Thus misleading thousands upon thousands of men.

---

**Five-character regulated verse**

The twenty-four gods are pure,
Three thousand merits and deeds complete.
Cold clouds connect to the earth’s axis,
The sacred sun fills the sky with light.
The Prince’s Son is most fit to plant,
How could the golden field be tilled?
Within this, the true wondrous principle—
Who says one cannot attain long life?

The Dao is penetrated, the Mysterious again penetrated,
Its name left to spread across the four seas.
Friends rely on a single staff,
Livelihood—two empty fists.
Seeking fruit, hesitating to plant,
Thinking of wine, instantly coining sacred money.
Who knows that coming to blend with the world,
Is not again to turn away from heaven?

Wondrous, wondrous within the wondrous,
Mysterious within the mysterious, even more mysterious.
In movement and speech, all expound the Dao,
In silence, all become immortals.
In the palm, like a pearl, strange,
In the sky, the moon gleams bright.
When one’s merit is complete in time,
Straight to the Great Luo Heaven ascend.

*The Pure Yang Perfected One’s Thoroughly Accomplished Collection, Volume the Lower, concludes.*
